value.0:
Some of the pages are worn beyond recognition, but you can make out most of the words.  This book describes the history and lore of the three moons, and what different combinations of their presence at night may portend.  It is said the Druids also have a calendar based on their cycles.

"Bràthair, the brother moon, rises on a 25 day cycle.  He is always low in the southern sky, and never as bright as the other two.

Piuthar, the sister moon, rises on the same 25 day cycle, but off by a few days.  It is said that the brother and sister moon dance across the southern sky each night, as if playing in the heavens.

Màthair, the mother moon, has a 32 day cycle.  She is the largest of the three, and shines brightly over the lands from the north.  Some believe to have seen the face of a women in the moon, smiling.

When the mother is out by herself, it is a sign of bad things to come.  When the children are out alone, expect foul weather in the coming days.

If the sister and mother are out together, expect good news of birth, or rebirth.  When all three are together in the night sky, there shall be peace across the lands."
